<FONT size="2">Goldman Sachs, as a participant in the financial
services industry, is subject to extensive regulation in
jurisdictions around the world. We face the risk of significant
intervention by regulatory authorities in all jurisdictions in
which we conduct business. Among other things, we could be fined
or prohibited from engaging in some of our business activities.
New laws or regulations or changes in enforcement of existing
laws or regulations applicable to our clients may also adversely
affect our businesses.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">As discussed under &#147;Regulation&#148; above,
the research departments of investment banks are the subject of
increased regulatory scrutiny which have led to increased
restrictions on the interaction between research analysts and
investment banking departments at securities firms. Various
non-U.S. jurisdictions have also changed or proposed changing
their requirements with respect to research matters. In
addition, several major securities firms, including Goldman
Sachs, have recently reached agreements in principle with
certain federal and state securities regulators and
self-regulatory organizations to resolve investigations into the
practices of their research departments. Some of the proposals
and restrictions could adversely impact our businesses, at least
in the short term.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">There have been a number of highly publicized
cases involving fraud or other misconduct by employees in the
financial services industry in recent years, and we run the risk
that employee misconduct could occur. It is not always possible
to deter or prevent employee misconduct and the precautions we
take to prevent and detect this activity may not be effective in
all cases.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Regulatory
Impact on Capital Markets</I></FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Recent financial scandals have led to insecurity
and uncertainty in the financial markets and contributed to
declines in capital markets during 2002. In response to these
scandals, the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 and the rules and rule
proposals (if adopted) of the SEC, the NYSE and Nasdaq
necessitate significant changes to corporate governance and
public disclosure. These provisions generally apply to companies
with securities listed on U.S. securities exchanges, and some
provisions apply to non-U.S. issuers with securities traded on
U.S. securities exchanges. To the extent that private companies,
in order to avoid becoming subject to these new requirements,
decide to forgo initial public offerings, our equity
underwriting business may be adversely affected and our ability
to successfully exit some of our merchant banking investments
may be adversely affected. Similarly, it is possible that the
imposition of those
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">19
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV align="left">
<FONT size="2">provisions on non-U.S. issuers may make these
issuers less likely to list their securities in the United
States or undertake merger or acquisition transactions that
would result in their securities being listed in the United
States. If these measures result in less activity by non-U.S.
issuers in the United States, the U.S. capital markets and our
investment banking business may be adversely affected.
</FONT>
</DIV>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The provisions of Sarbanes-Oxley and the NYSE and
Nasdaq corporate governance proposals, coupled with existing
economic uncertainty, have diverted many companies&#146;
attention away from capital market transactions, including
securities offerings and acquisition and disposition
transactions. It is unclear how long this uncertainty and
diversion will last, but so long as it does, it will have a
negative impact on our investment banking business. In addition,
proposed accounting and disclosure changes, including those
relating to off-balance-sheet entities, may have an adverse
effect on our financial advisory and other revenues relating to
structured finance transactions.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Competition
and Conflicts of Interest</I></FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The financial services industry&nbsp;&#151; and
all of our businesses&nbsp;&#151; are intensely competitive, and
we expect them to remain so. We compete on the basis of a number
of factors, including transaction execution, our products and
services, innovation, reputation and price. We believe that we
may experience pricing pressures in the future as some of our
competitors seek to increase market share by reducing prices. In
recent years, there has been substantial consolidation and
convergence among companies in the financial services industry.
U.S. federal legislation, which significantly expanded the
activities permissible for firms affiliated with a U.S. bank,
may accelerate this consolidation and further increase
competition. This trend toward consolidation and convergence has
significantly increased the capital base and geographic reach of
our competitors. This trend has also hastened the globalization
of the securities and other financial services markets. As a
result, we have had to commit capital to support our
international operations and to execute large global
transactions.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Our reputation is one of our most important
assets. As we have expanded the scope of our business and our
client base, we increasingly have to address conflicts of
interest. We have extensive procedures and controls that are
designed to address these issues. However, appropriately dealing
with conflicts of interest is complex and difficult and our
reputation could be damaged if we fail, or appear to fail, to
deal appropriately with conflicts of interest.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Technology is fundamental to our overall business
strategy. The growth of the Internet and electronic trading, and
the introduction of new technologies, is changing our business
and presenting us with new challenges. Securities, futures and
options transactions are now being conducted through the
Internet and other alternative, non-traditional trading systems,
and it appears that the trend toward alternative trading systems
will continue and probably accelerate. Some of these alternative
trading systems compete with our trading businesses, including
our specialist businesses. A dramatic increase in electronic
trading may adversely affect our commission and trading
revenues, including our market-making revenues, reduce our
participation in the trading markets and associated access to
market information and lead to the creation of new and stronger
competitors. These developments may also require us to make
additional investments in technology or trading systems.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Recruiting
and Employee Retention</I></FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Our performance is largely dependent on the
talents and efforts of highly skilled individuals. Competition
in the financial services industry for qualified employees is
intense. In addition, competition with businesses outside the
financial services industry for the most highly skilled
individuals has become more intense as the economic downturn has
lowered average compensation within the financial services
industry significantly. Our continued ability to compete
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">20
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV align="left">
<FONT size="2">effectively in our businesses depends on our
ability to attract new employees and to retain and motivate our
existing employees. Changes in the business environment may
cause us to move employees from one business to another or to
reduce the number of employees in certain businesses; this may
cause temporary disruptions as our employees adapt to new roles
and may reduce our ability to take advantage of improvements in
the business environment.
</FONT>
</DIV>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Acquisitions</I></FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">We expect the growth of our core businesses to
come principally through internal expansion and also through
acquisitions. To the extent we make acquisitions or enter into
combinations, such as our combination with Spear, Leeds &#38;
Kellogg in October&nbsp;2000, we face numerous risks and
uncertainties combining the businesses and systems, including
the need to combine accounting and data processing systems and
management controls and to integrate relationships with
customers and business partners. We may not be able to meet
these operational and business challenges.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>International
Operations</I></FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In conducting our businesses and maintaining and
supporting our operations around the world, we are subject to
political, economic, legal, operational and other risks that are
inherent in operating in many countries, including risks of
possible nationalization, expropriation, price controls, capital
controls, exchange controls and other restrictive governmental
actions, as well as the outbreak of hostilities. In many
countries, the laws and regulations applicable to the securities
and financial services industries are uncertain and evolving,
and it may be difficult for us to determine the exact
requirements of local laws in every market. Our inability to
remain in compliance with local laws in a particular foreign
market could have a significant and negative effect not only on
our businesses in that market but also on our reputation
generally. We are also subject to the risk that transactions we
structure might not be legally enforceable in all cases.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In the last several years, various emerging
market countries have experienced severe economic and financial
disruptions, including significant devaluations of their
currencies, capital and currency exchange controls, and low or
negative growth rates in their economies. The possible effects
of these conditions include an adverse impact on our businesses
and increased volatility in financial markets generally.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Shares
Available for Sale</I></FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">A significant amount of our outstanding shares of
common stock are held by our former limited partners. While a
significant number of these shares are subject to restrictions
on transfer, our board of directors and/or the
shareholders&#146; committee under our shareholders&#146;
agreement have in the past waived, and may in the future from
time to time waive, these transfer restrictions. Future sales of
substantial amounts of common stock, or the perception that such
sales may occur, could adversely affect the prevailing market
price of our common stock.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">Cautionary Statement Pursuant to The Private
Securities</FONT></B>

<DIV align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">Litigation Reform Act of 1995</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">We have included or incorporated by reference in
this Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K, and from time to time our
management may make, statements that may constitute
&#147;forward-looking statements&#148; within the meaning of the
safe harbor provisions of The Private Securities Litigation
Reform Act of 1995. Forward-looking statements are not
historical facts but instead represent only our belief regarding
future events, many of which, by their nature, are inherently
uncertain and outside of our control. These statements include
statements other than historical information or statements of
current condition and may relate to our future plans and
objectives and results, among other things, and may also include
our belief regarding the effect of various legal
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">21
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV align="left">
<FONT size="2">proceedings, as set forth under &#147;Legal
Proceedings&#148; in Part&nbsp;I, Item&nbsp;3 of this Annual
Report on Form&nbsp;10-K, as well as statements about the
objectives and effectiveness of our liquidity policies, and
statements about our investment banking transaction backlog,
incorporated by reference in Part&nbsp;II, Item&nbsp;7 of this
Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K. It is possible that our actual
results may differ, possibly materially, from the anticipated
results indicated in these forward-looking statements. Important
factors that could cause actual results to differ from those in
the forward-looking statements include, among others, those
discussed below and under &#147;&#151;&nbsp;Certain Factors That
May Affect Our Business.&#148;
</FONT>
</DIV>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In the case of statements about our investment
banking transaction backlog, such statements are subject to the
risk that the terms of these transactions may be modified or
that they may not be completed at all; therefore, the net
revenues that we expect to earn from these transactions may
differ, possibly materially, from those currently expected.
Important factors that could result in a modification of the
terms of a transaction or a transaction not being completed
include, in the case of underwriting transactions, a decline in
general economic conditions, outbreak of hostilities, volatility
in the securities markets generally or an adverse development
with respect to the issuer of the securities and, in the case of
financial advisory transactions, a decline in the securities
markets, an adverse development with respect to a party to the
transaction or a failure to obtain a required regulatory
approval.
</FONT>

<!-- link2 "Item 2. Properties" -->

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">Item&nbsp;2.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Properties</I></FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Our principal executive offices are located at 85
Broad Street, New York, New York, and comprise approximately
969,000 square feet of leased space, pursuant to a lease
agreement expiring in June&nbsp;2008 (with options to renew for
up to 20 additional years). We also occupy over 680,000 square
feet at One New York Plaza under lease agreements expiring
primarily in September&nbsp;2004 (with options to renew for up
to ten additional years), and we lease space at various other
locations in the New York metropolitan area. In total, we lease
over 5.2&nbsp;million square feet in the New York metropolitan
area. We have additional offices in the United States and
elsewhere in the Americas. Together, these offices comprise
approximately 1.7&nbsp;million square feet of leased space.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">We own approximately four acres of land in Jersey
City, New Jersey, a portion of which we are using for the
construction of an office building. This project is being
developed to complement our offices in lower Manhattan. The
initial phase of development is expected to include
approximately 1.4&nbsp;million square feet of office space, with
occupancy planned in phases beginning in 2004.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">We also have offices in Europe, Asia, Africa and
Australia. In Europe, we have offices that total approximately
1.9&nbsp;million square feet. Our European headquarters is
located in London at Peterborough Court, pursuant to a lease
which expires in 2016. In total, we lease approximately
1.4&nbsp;million square feet in London through various leases,
relating to various properties.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In Asia and Australia, we have offices that total
approximately 1&nbsp;million square feet. Our headquarters in
this region are in Tokyo, at the ARK Mori Building, and in Hong
Kong, at the Cheung Kong Center. In Tokyo, we currently lease
approximately 400,000 square feet under renewable leases with
current terms extending, in some cases, to June&nbsp;2005. In
Hong Kong, we currently lease approximately 300,000 square feet
under lease agreements, the majority of which expire in fiscal
2012.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Our occupancy expenses include costs associated
with office space held in excess of our current requirements,
primarily due to the impact of the levels of current business
activity on our previously anticipated growth in headcount. This
excess space is being held for potential future growth. We
continually review our space requirements and may, from time to
time, reduce capacity through the use of sublease contracts or
early termination agreements. We may incur costs in connection
with such reductions in our global office space. Where we have
unoccupied
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">22
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV align="left">
<FONT size="2">space that we may occupy in the future, we will
continue to charge the underlying operating costs to earnings as
incurred.
</FONT>
</DIV>

<!-- link2 "Item 3. Legal Proceedings" -->

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">Item&nbsp;3.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Legal
Proceedings</I></FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">We are involved in a number of judicial,
regulatory and arbitration proceedings (including those
described below) concerning matters arising in connection with
the conduct of our businesses. We believe, based on currently
available information, that the results of such proceedings, in
the aggregate, will not have a material adverse effect on our
financial condition, but might be material to our operating
results for any particular period, depending, in part, upon the
operating results for such period.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></B><I><FONT size="2">IPO
Process Matters</FONT></I>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Goldman Sachs Group, Inc. and Goldman, Sachs
&#38; Co. are among the numerous financial services companies
that have been named as defendants in a variety of lawsuits
alleging improprieties in the process by which those companies
participated in the underwriting of public offerings in recent
years.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Certain purported class actions have been brought
in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York
by purchasers of securities in public offerings, who claim that
the defendants engaged in conspiracies in violation of federal
antitrust laws in connection with these offerings. The
plaintiffs in each instance seek treble damages as well as
injunctive relief. One of the actions, which was commenced on
August&nbsp;21, 1998, alleges that the defendants have conspired
to discourage or restrict the resale of securities for a period
after the offerings, including by imposing &#147;penalty
bids&#148;. Defendants moved to dismiss the complaint in
November&nbsp;1998. The plaintiffs amended their complaint in
February&nbsp;1999, modifying their claims in various ways,
including limiting the proposed class to retail purchasers of
public offerings. The defendants moved to dismiss the amended
complaint on May&nbsp;7, 1999, the motion was granted by a
decision dated December&nbsp;7, 2000, and the plaintiffs&#146;
motion for reconsideration of that decision was denied by an
order dated January&nbsp;22, 2001. Plaintiffs appealed, and by a
decision dated December&nbsp;20, 2002, the U.S. Court of Appeals
for the Second Circuit affirmed the dismissal of their complaint.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Several other actions were commenced, beginning
on November&nbsp;3, 1998 by purchasers of securities in public
offerings as well as certain purported issuers of such
offerings, that allege that the defendants, many of whom are
also named in the other action discussed above, have conspired
to fix at 7% the discount that underwriting syndicates receive
from issuers of shares in certain offerings. On March&nbsp;15,
1999, the purchaser plaintiffs filed a consolidated amended
complaint. The defendants moved to dismiss the consolidated
amended complaint on April&nbsp;29, 1999. On February&nbsp;14,
2001, the federal district court granted with prejudice the
defendants&#146; motion to dismiss the claims asserted by the
purchasers of securities on the ground that they lacked
antitrust standing. The plaintiffs in those actions appealed,
and by a decision dated December&nbsp;13, 2002, the U.S. Court
of Appeals for the Second Circuit vacated the dismissal on the
ground that the lower court had engaged in improper fact-finding
on the motion and remanded for consideration of other potential
bases for dismissal. On September&nbsp;28, 2001, the defendants
moved to dismiss the complaints filed by the issuer plaintiffs
on statute of limitations grounds. On September&nbsp;25, 2002,
the federal district court denied the underwriter
defendants&#146; motion to dismiss.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Goldman, Sachs &#38; Co. is one of numerous
financial services firms that have been named as defendants in
purported class actions filed beginning on March&nbsp;9, 2001 in
the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York by
purchasers of securities in public offerings, who claim that the
defendants engaged in a conspiracy to &#147;tie&#148;
allocations in certain offerings to higher customer brokerage
commission rates as well as purchase orders in the aftermarket,
in violation
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">23
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV align="left">
<FONT size="2">of federal antitrust laws. The plaintiffs filed a
consolidated amended complaint on January&nbsp;2, 2002. The
defendants moved to dismiss the consolidated amended complaint
on May&nbsp;24, 2002. Goldman, Sachs &#38; Co. has also,
together with other underwriters in certain offerings as well as
the issuers and certain of their officers and directors, been
named as a defendant in a number of related lawsuits alleging,
among other things, that the prospectuses for the offerings
violated the federal securities laws by failing to disclose the
existence of the alleged &#147;tying&#148; arrangements. On
July&nbsp;1, 2002, the underwriter defendants moved to dismiss
those complaints. By an opinion and order dated
February&nbsp;19, 2003, the federal district court denied the
motion to dismiss in all material respects relating to the
underwriter defendants.
</FONT>
</DIV>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Goldman, Sachs &#38; Co. has been named as a
defendant in several actions alleging that the firm
intentionally underpriced public offerings for certain issuers.
Each of the actions seeks, among other things, consequential
damages resulting from the alleged lower amount of offering
proceeds. Two of the lawsuits are purported shareholder
derivative actions commenced on May&nbsp;3, 2002 in California
Superior Court for Santa Clara County and San Mateo County which
Goldman, Sachs &#38; Co. has removed to the U.S. District Court
for the Northern District of California. On August&nbsp;5, 2002,
Goldman, Sachs &#38; Co. moved for judgment on the pleadings in
those actions, the motions were granted by decisions dated
October&nbsp;31, 2002 and November&nbsp;6, 2002, and plaintiffs
in both cases have appealed. Goldman, Sachs &#38; Co. has also
been named as a defendant in a similar underpricing action
brought in New York Supreme Court, New York County on
May&nbsp;15, 2002 by an official committee of unsecured
creditors on behalf of an issuer which is in bankruptcy. On
August&nbsp;1, 2002, Goldman, Sachs&nbsp;&#38; Co. moved to
dismiss that complaint.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Goldman Sachs Group, Inc. has also been named
as a defendant in a purported shareholder derivative action
commenced in Delaware Court of Chancery on October&nbsp;23, 2002
alleging that certain officers and directors of eBay, Inc. (who
are also defendants), aided and abetted by The Goldman Sachs
Group, Inc., breached their fiduciary duties and usurped
corporate opportunities by receiving allocations of initial
public offerings as customers of The Goldman Sachs Group, Inc.
Defendants moved to dismiss the complaint on December&nbsp;23,
2002.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Goldman Sachs Group, Inc. has, together with
other underwriters in certain offerings, received subpoenas for
documents and information from various governmental agencies and
the U.S. House of Representatives Committee on Financial
Services in connection with investigations relating to the
public offering process. In particular, the Securities and
Exchange Commission has been conducting an investigation of
certain allocation practices employed by Goldman, Sachs &#38;
Co. Goldman Sachs is cooperating with the investigations.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></B><I><FONT size="2">Stock
Options Antitrust Litigation</FONT></I>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Hull Trading Co. L.L.C. and Spear, Leeds &#38;
Kellogg, L.P., affiliates of The Goldman Sachs Group, Inc., are
among the numerous market makers in listed equity options which
have been named as defendants, together with five national
securities exchanges, in a purported class action brought in the
U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York on
behalf of persons who purchased or sold listed equity options.
The consolidated class action complaint, filed on
October&nbsp;4, 1999 (which consolidated certain previously
pending actions and added Hull Trading Co. L.L.C. and other
market makers as defendants), generally alleges that the
defendants engaged in a conspiracy to preclude the multiple
listing of certain equity options on the exchanges and seeks
treble damages under the antitrust laws as well as injunctive
relief. Certain of the parties, including Hull Trading Co.
L.L.C. and Spear, Leeds &#38; Kellogg, L.P., have entered into a
stipulation of settlement, subject to court approval, pursuant
to which Hull Trading Co. L.L.C. will be required to pay an
aggregate of $2.48 million and Spear, Leeds &#38; Kellogg, L.P.
an aggregate of $19.59 million. On February&nbsp;14, 2001, the
federal district court granted the motion of certain
non-settling defendants for summary judgment. By a decision
dated April&nbsp;24, 2001, the district court ruled that in
light of that order granting summary judgment, the court
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">24
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV align="left">
<FONT size="2">lacked jurisdiction to entertain the proposed
settlement. Plaintiffs appealed, and by a decision dated
January&nbsp;9, 2003, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second
Circuit affirmed the grant of summary judgment, but held that
the decision did not divest the lower court of jurisdiction to
entertain the proposed settlement, and remanded for further
proceedings.
</FONT>
</DIV>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <I><FONT size="2">Rockefeller Center Properties, Inc.
    Litigation</FONT></I></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Several former shareholders of Rockefeller Center
Properties, Inc. brought purported class actions in the U.S.
District Court for the District of Delaware and the Delaware
Court of Chancery arising from the acquisition of Rockefeller
Center Properties, Inc. by an investor group in July&nbsp;1996.
The defendants in the actions include, among others, Goldman,
Sachs &#38; Co., Whitehall Real Estate Partnership V, a merchant
banking fund advised by Goldman, Sachs &#38; Co., a Goldman,
Sachs &#38; Co. managing director and other members of the
investor group. The federal court actions, which have since been
consolidated, were filed beginning on November&nbsp;15, 1996,
and the state court action was filed on May&nbsp;29, 1998.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The complaints generally allege that the proxy
statement disseminated to former Rockefeller Center Properties,
Inc. stockholders in connection with the transaction was
deficient, in violation of the disclosure requirements of the
federal securities laws. The plaintiffs are seeking, among other
things, unspecified damages, rescission of the acquisition,
and/or disgorgement.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In a series of decisions, the federal district
court granted summary judgment dismissing all the claims in the
federal action. The plaintiffs appealed those rulings. On
July&nbsp;19, 1999, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Third
Circuit rendered its decision affirming in part and vacating in
part the lower court&#146;s entry of summary judgment dismissing
the action. With respect to the claim as to which summary
judgment was vacated, the appellate court held that the district
court had committed a procedural error in converting the
defendants&#146; motion to dismiss into a motion for summary
judgment and remanded for the district court to reconsider that
claim under appropriate standards applicable to motions to
dismiss. Plaintiffs subsequently amended their complaint as to
the remanded claim, defendants renewed their motion to dismiss
with respect to the amended complaint, and the motion was
granted by the federal district court on March&nbsp;12, 2001.
Plaintiffs appealed, and by a decision dated November&nbsp;8,
2002, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit affirmed
the dismissal order, and by a decision dated December&nbsp;11,
2002 denied rehearing.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The state action has been stayed pending
disposition of the federal action.
</FONT>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <I><FONT size="2">AMF Securities Litigation</FONT></I></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Goldman Sachs Group, L.P., Goldman, Sachs
&#38; Co. and a Goldman, Sachs &#38;&nbsp;Co. managing director
have been named as defendants in several purported class action
lawsuits beginning on April&nbsp;27, 1999 in the U.S. District
Court for the Southern District of New York brought on behalf of
purchasers of stock of AMF Bowling, Inc. in an underwritten
initial public offering of 15,525,000 shares of common stock in
November&nbsp;1997 at a price of $19.50 per share. Defendants
are AMF Bowling, Inc., certain officers and directors of AMF
Bowling, Inc. (including the Goldman, Sachs &#38; Co. managing
director), and the lead underwriters of the offering (including
Goldman, Sachs &#38; Co.). The consolidated amended complaint
alleges violations of the disclosure requirements of the federal
securities laws and seeks compensatory damages and/or
rescission. The complaint also asserts that The Goldman Sachs
Group, L.P. and the Goldman, Sachs &#38; Co. managing director
are liable as controlling persons of AMF Bowling, Inc. under the
federal securities laws because certain merchant banking funds
managed by Goldman Sachs owned a majority of the outstanding
common stock of AMF Bowling, Inc. and the managing director
served as its chairman at the time of the offering. On
December&nbsp;22, 1999, the defendants moved to dismiss the
complaint. By a decision dated March&nbsp;22, 2001, the federal
district court denied the motion. By a decision dated
March&nbsp;25, 2002, the federal district court granted
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">25
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV align="left">
<FONT size="2">plaintiffs&#146; motion for class certification
with respect to a class under Section&nbsp;11 of the Securities
Act of 1933, but denied the motion with respect to a subclass
under Section&nbsp;12 of the Securities Act. By a decision dated
May&nbsp;21, 2002, the federal district court reconsidered its
March&nbsp;25, 2002 decision with respect to plaintiffs&#146;
motion for class certification and determined that the class
includes persons who purchased AMF stock pursuant to the initial
public offering prior to February&nbsp;26, 1999.
</FONT>
</DIV>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On July&nbsp;30, 2001, AMF Bowling, Inc. filed
for protection under the U.S.&nbsp;bankruptcy laws.
</FONT>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <I><FONT size="2">Iridium Securities Litigation</FONT></I></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Goldman, Sachs &#38; Co. has been named as a
defendant in two purported class action lawsuits commenced,
beginning on May&nbsp;26, 1999, in the U.S. District Court for
the District of Columbia brought on behalf of purchasers of
Class&nbsp;A common stock of Iridium World Communications, Ltd.
in a January&nbsp;1999 underwritten secondary offering of
7,500,000 shares of Class&nbsp;A common stock at a price of
$33.40 per share, as well as in the secondary market. The
defendants in the actions include Iridium, certain of its
officers and directors, Motorola, Inc. (an investor in Iridium)
and the lead underwriters in the offering, including Goldman,
Sachs &#38; Co. On May&nbsp;13, 2002, plaintiffs filed a
consolidated amended complaint alleging substantively identical
claims as the original complaints. On July&nbsp;15, 2002, the
defendants moved to dismiss the consolidated amended complaint.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The complaints in both actions allege violations
of the disclosure requirements of the federal securities laws
and seek compensatory and/or rescissory damages. Goldman, Sachs
&#38; Co. underwrote 996,500 shares of common stock and Goldman
Sachs International underwrote 320,625 shares of common stock
for a total offering price of approximately $44&nbsp;million.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On August&nbsp;13, 1999, Iridium World
Communications, Ltd. filed for protection under the U.S.
bankruptcy laws.
</FONT>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <I><FONT size="2">Laidlaw Bondholders Litigation</FONT></I></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Goldman, Sachs &#38; Co. has been named as a
defendant in a purported class action filed on
September&nbsp;22, 2000 in the U.S. District Court for the
Southern District of New York arising from certain offerings of
debentures by Laidlaw, Inc. from 1997 to 1999. The defendants
include Laidlaw, Inc., certain of its officers and directors,
the lead underwriters for the offerings (including Goldman,
Sachs &#38; Co., which was lead manager in the offerings), and
Laidlaw&#146;s outside auditors. The offerings included a total
of $1.125 billion principal amount of debentures, of which
Goldman, Sachs &#38; Co. underwrote $286.25 million.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The lawsuit, brought by certain institutional
purchasers of the debentures, alleges that the prospectuses
issued in connection with the offerings were false and
misleading in violation of the disclosure requirements of the
federal securities laws. The plaintiffs are seeking, among other
things, unspecified damages. By an order of the Judicial Panel
on Multi-District Litigation filed on April&nbsp;19, 2001, the
lawsuit was transferred to the U.S. District Court for the
District of South Carolina for purposes of consolidated or
coordinated pretrial proceedings with related actions in that
court pertaining to Safety Kleen Corporation and Laidlaw, Inc.
On January&nbsp;8, 2002, the parties entered into a Preliminary
Memorandum of Understanding with respect to a settlement of the
lawsuit pursuant to which Goldman, Sachs &#38; Co. would
contribute approximately $2.5&nbsp;million toward a settlement
fund. The settlement has been embodied in a settlement
agreement, and by order dated December&nbsp;19, 2002, the South
Carolina Court approved the settlement. The settlement is still
subject to, among other things, the confirmation of a
satisfactory plan of reorganization of Laidlaw, Inc.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On June&nbsp;28, 2001, Laidlaw, Inc. filed for
bankruptcy protection.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">26
</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <I><FONT size="2">World Online Litigation</FONT></I></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Several lawsuits have been commenced in the
Netherlands courts based on alleged misstatements and omissions
relating to the initial public offering of World Online in
March&nbsp;2000. Goldman Sachs and ABN AMRO Rothschild served as
joint global coordinators of the offering, which raised
approximately
<FONT face="times new roman,times">&#128;</FONT>2.9&nbsp;billion.
Goldman Sachs International underwrote 20,268,846 shares and
Goldman, Sachs &#38; Co. underwrote 6,756,282 shares for a total
offering price of approximately
<FONT face="times new roman,times">&#128;</FONT>1.16&nbsp;billion.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On September&nbsp;11, 2000, several Dutch World
Online shareholders as well as a Dutch entity purporting to
represent the interests of certain World Online shareholders
commenced a proceeding in Amsterdam District Court against
&#147;ABN AMRO Bank N.V., also acting under the name of ABN AMRO
Rothschild&#148;, alleging misrepresentations and omissions
relating to the initial public offering of World Online. The
lawsuit seeks, among other things, the return of the purchase
price of the shares purchased by the plaintiffs or unspecified
damages.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In March&nbsp;2001, a Dutch shareholders
association initiated legal proceedings in Amsterdam District
Court in connection with the World Online offering. Goldman
Sachs International is named as a defendant in the writ served
on its Dutch attorneys on March&nbsp;14, 2001. The amount of
damages sought is not specified in the writ. Goldman Sachs
International filed its Statement of Defense on January&nbsp;16,
2002 and a rejoinder on January&nbsp;14, 2003.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></B><I><FONT size="2">Owens
Corning, Inc. Bondholder Litigation</FONT></I>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Goldman, Sachs &#38; Co. has been named as a
defendant in a purported class action filed on April&nbsp;27,
2001 in the U.S. District Court for the District of
Massachusetts arising from a 1998 offering by Owens Corning,
Inc. of two series of its notes. The defendants include certain
of Owens Corning&#146;s officers and directors and the
underwriters for the offering (including Goldman, Sachs &#38;
Co., which was the lead manager in the offering). The offering
included a total of $550&nbsp;million principal amount of notes,
of which Goldman, Sachs &#38; Co. underwrote $275 million.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The lawsuit, brought by certain institutional
purchasers of the notes, alleges that the prospectus issued in
connection with the offering was false and misleading in
violation of the disclosure requirements of the federal
securities laws. The plaintiffs are seeking, among other things,
unspecified damages. The underwriter defendants moved to dismiss
the complaint on November&nbsp;14, 2001. By a decision dated
August&nbsp;26, 2002, the federal district court denied the
underwriter defendants&#146; motion to dismiss.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On October&nbsp;5, 2000, Owens Corning, Inc.
filed for protection under the U.S. bankruptcy laws.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></B><I><FONT size="2">Research
Independence Matters</FONT></I>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Goldman Sachs Group, Inc. and its affiliates,
together with other financial services firms, have received
requests for information from various governmental agencies in
connection with their review of research independence issues,
including the New York State Attorney General, the Utah Attorney
General, the NYSE (which has issued a joint inquiry together
with the SEC and NASD), the U.S. Attorney&#146;s Office for the
Southern District of New York, and the U.S. House of
Representatives Committee on Financial Services. Goldman Sachs
is cooperating with their requests. On December&nbsp;20, 2002,
as part of a proposed global settlement involving the leading
securities firms operating in the United States, agreements in
principle were announced among Goldman, Sachs &#38; Co. and the
SEC, the NYSE, the NASD, the Utah Division of Securities, the
New York State Attorney General and the North American
Securities Administrators Association (in the case of Utah and
NASAA, on behalf of state securities regulators) to resolve
their investigations of Goldman Sachs relating to investment
research analysts&#146; conflicts of interest. Pursuant to the
agreements in principle, Goldman, Sachs &#38; Co. has
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">27
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV align="left">
<FONT size="2">agreed, among other things, to (i)&nbsp;pay $50
million in retrospective relief, (ii)&nbsp;contribute
$50&nbsp;million over five years to provide independent
third-party research to clients, (iii)&nbsp;contribute $10
million for investor education and (iv)&nbsp;adopt internal
structural and other safeguards to further ensure the integrity
of Goldman, Sachs&nbsp;&#38; Co. investment research. In
connection with the agreements, the firm also expects to be
joining the other leading securities firms who are part of the
proposed global settlement in an initiative that generally will
prohibit the allocation of shares in initial public offerings to
executives and directors of public companies.
</FONT>
</DIV>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Goldman, Sachs &#38; Co. is one of several
investment firms that have been named as defendants in
substantively identical purported class actions filed in the
U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York on
August&nbsp;30, 2002 and September&nbsp;12, 2002 alleging
violations of the federal securities laws in connection with
research coverage of Covad Communications Company and Allied
Riser Communications Corp., respectively. The actions seek
compensatory damages. On December&nbsp;26, 2002, defendants
moved to dismiss the action relating to Covad Communications
Company, and on February&nbsp;6, 2003, the motion was granted
with leave to replead.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></B><I><FONT size="2">Enron
Exchangeable Notes Litigation</FONT></I>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Goldman, Sachs &#38;&nbsp;Co. and/or co-managing
underwriters have been named as defendants in certain purported
securities class and individual actions commenced beginning on
December&nbsp;14, 2001 in the U.S. District Court for the
Southern District of Texas and California Superior Court brought
by purchasers of $222,500,000 of Exchangeable Notes of Enron
Corp. in August&nbsp;1999. The notes were mandatorily
exchangeable in 2002 into shares of Enron Oil &#38; Gas Company
held by Enron Corp. or their cash equivalent. The complaints
also name as defendants certain past and present officers and
directors of Enron Corp. and the company&#146;s outside
accounting firm. The complaints generally allege violations of
the disclosure requirements of the federal securities laws
and/or state law, and seek compensatory damages. Goldman, Sachs
&#38; Co. underwrote $111,250,000 principal amount of the notes.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Several funds which allegedly sustained
investment losses of approximately $125&nbsp;million in
connection with secondary market purchases of the notes as well
as Zero Coupon Convertible Notes of Enron Corp. commenced an
action in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of
New York on January&nbsp;16, 2002. The lawsuit names as
defendants the underwriters of the August&nbsp;1999 offering as
well as the company&#146;s outside accounting firm, and alleges
violations of the disclosure requirements of the federal
securities laws, fraud and misrepresentation. On March&nbsp;20,
2002, Goldman, Sachs &#38; Co. moved to dismiss the complaint.
By an Order dated June&nbsp;24, 2002, the Judicial Panel on
Multidistrict Litigation entered an order transferring that
action to the Texas federal district court for purposes of
coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with other
matters relating to Enron.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On December&nbsp;2, 2001, Enron Corp. filed for
protection under the U.S. bankruptcy laws.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></B><I><FONT size="2">Exodus
Securities Litigation</FONT></I>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">By an amended complaint dated July&nbsp;11, 2002,
Goldman, Sachs &#38; Co. and the other lead underwriters for the
February&nbsp;2001 offering of 13,000,000 shares of common stock
and $575,000,000 of 5&nbsp;1/4% convertible subordinated notes
of Exodus Communications, Inc. were added as defendants in a
purported class action pending in the U.S. District Court for
the Northern District of California. The complaint, which also
names as defendants certain officers and directors of Exodus
Communications, Inc., alleges violations of the disclosure
requirements of the federal securities laws and seeks
compensatory damages. On October&nbsp;23, 2002, the underwriter
defendants moved to dismiss the complaint. Goldman, Sachs &#38;
Co. underwrote 5,200,000 shares of common stock for a total
offering price of approximately $96,200,000, and $230,000,000
principal amount of the notes.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">28
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On September&nbsp;26, 2001, Exodus
Communications, Inc. filed for protection under the U.S.
bankruptcy laws.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></B><I><FONT size="2">Montana
Power Shareholders Litigation</FONT></I>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Goldman, Sachs &#38; Co. and The Goldman Sachs
Group, Inc. have been named as defendants in a purported class
action commenced against it on October&nbsp;1, 2001 in Montana
District Court, Second Judicial District on behalf of
shareholders of Montana Power Company. The complaint generally
alleges that Montana Power Company violated Montana law by
failing to procure shareholder approval of certain corporate
strategies and transactions, that the company&#146;s board
breached its fiduciary duties in pursuing those strategies and
transactions, and that Goldman, Sachs &#38; Co. rendered
negligent advice as well as aided and abetted the board&#146;s
breaches in its role as financial advisor to the company. The
complaint seeks, among other things, compensatory damages. In
addition to Goldman, Sachs &#38; Co. and The Goldman Sachs
Group, Inc., the defendants include Montana Power Company,
certain of its officers and directors, an outside law firm for
the Montana Power Company, and certain companies that purchased
assets from Montana Power Company. The Montana state court
denied motions to dismiss by a decision dated August&nbsp;1,
2002. On January&nbsp;9, 2003, another defendant removed the
action to the U.S. District Court for the District of Montana,
and the plaintiffs moved to remand the action to state court on
February&nbsp;7, 2003.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></B><I><FONT size="2">WorldCom
Bondholders Litigation</FONT></I>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Goldman, Sachs &#38; Co. and other underwriters
of WorldCom, Inc. bonds have been named as defendants in certain
purported securities class and individual actions commenced
beginning on July&nbsp;19, 2002 alleging that the offering
materials issued in connection with certain securities offerings
were false and misleading. Certain of the lawsuits (some of
which were originally filed in various state courts and removed
to federal court) have been transferred by order of the Judicial
Panel on Multidistrict Litigation to the U.S.&nbsp;District
Court for the Southern District of New York, and similar
requests for transfer are pending in other actions. Goldman,
Sachs &#38; Co. underwrote $75,000,000 principal amount of 8%
notes due 2006 in a May&nbsp;24, 2000 offering out of a total
principal amount of $1,250,000,000 of the notes. Among the
defendants in these actions in addition to the underwriters are
WorldCom, Inc., certain of WorldCom, Inc.&#146;s present or
former officers and/or directors, and/or WorldCom, Inc.&#146;s
outside accounting firm. Each of these actions seeks, among
other things, compensatory damages.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On July&nbsp;21, 2002, WorldCom, Inc. filed for
protection under the U.S. bankruptcy laws.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></B><I><FONT size="2">Asia
Global Crossing Securities Litigation</FONT></I>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Goldman, Sachs &#38; Co. has been named as a
defendant in several purported class action lawsuits commenced,
beginning on November&nbsp;8, 2002, in the U.S. District Court
for the Southern District of New York and the Central District
of California brought on behalf of purchasers of common stock of
Asia Global Crossing Corp. in a October&nbsp;2000 initial public
offering of 68,000,000 shares of common stock at a price of $7
per share. The defendants in the actions include Asia Global
Crossing Corp., certain of its officers and directors, and the
lead underwriters in the offering, including Goldman, Sachs
&#38; Co. The complaints allege violations of the disclosure
requirements of the federal securities laws and seek
compensatory and/or rescissory damages. Goldman, Sachs &#38; Co.
underwrote 20,519,000 shares of common stock for a total
offering price of approximately $145 million.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On November&nbsp;17, 2002, Asia Global Crossing
Corp. filed for protection under the U.S. bankruptcy laws.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">29
</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></B><I><FONT size="2">Global
Crossing Securities Litigation</FONT></I>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Goldman Sachs Group, Inc. and Goldman, Sachs
&#38; Co. have been added as defendants in a purported class
action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern
District of New York relating to Global Crossing, Ltd. The
consolidated amended complaint, filed on January&nbsp;28, 2003,
includes claims relating to Global Crossing, Ltd.&#146;s
concurrent April&nbsp;2000 offerings of 43 million shares of
common stock at $33 per share and 4 million shares of
6&nbsp;3/4% cumulative preferred stock at $250 per share.
Goldman, Sachs &#38; Co. acted as a co-lead underwriter of both
offerings, underwriting 12.9 million shares of common stock and
400,000 shares of convertible preferred stock. The defendants in
the action as to such claims include certain officers and
directors of Global Crossing, Ltd., the lead underwriters in the
offerings, and the company&#146;s former outside auditors. The
complaint alleges violations of the disclosure requirements of
the federal securities laws as to such offerings and seeks
compensatory and/or rescissory damages.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On January&nbsp;28, 2002, Global Crossing, Ltd.
filed for protection under the U.S. bankruptcy laws.
</FONT>

<!-- link2 "Item 4. Submission of Matters to a Vote of Security Holders" -->

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">Item&nbsp;4.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Submission
of Matters to a Vote of Security Holders</I></FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">There were no matters submitted to a vote of
security holders during the fourth quarter of our fiscal year
ended November&nbsp;29, 2002.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">30
</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">EXECUTIVE OFFICERS OF THE GOLDMAN SACHS GROUP,
INC.</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Set forth below are the name, age, present title,
principal occupation, and certain biographical information for
the past five years for our executive officers as of
February&nbsp;1, 2003, all of whom have been appointed by and
serve at the pleasure of our board of directors.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">Henry M. Paulson, Jr., 56</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Mr.&nbsp;Paulson has been our Chairman and Chief
Executive Officer since May&nbsp;1999, and has been a director
since August&nbsp;1998. He was Co-Chairman and Chief Executive
Officer or Co-Chief Executive Officer of The Goldman Sachs
Group,&nbsp;L.P. from June&nbsp;1998 to May&nbsp;1999 and served
as Chief Operating Officer from December&nbsp;1994 to
June&nbsp;1998. Mr.&nbsp;Paulson is not on the board of any
public companies other than Goldman Sachs. He is a member of the
Board of Directors of the NYSE. In addition, Mr.&nbsp;Paulson is
affiliated with certain non-profit organizations, including as a
member of the Board of Directors of Catalyst. He also serves on
the Advisory Board of the J.L.&nbsp;Kellogg Graduate School of
Management at Northwestern University and is a member of the
Board of the Dean&#146;s Advisors of the Harvard Business
School. He is a member of the Advisory Board of the Tsinghua
University School of Economics and Management and a member of
the Governing Board of the Indian School of Business. He is also
a member of the Board of Governors of The Nature Conservancy,
Co-Chairman of the Asia/ Pacific Council of The Nature
Conservancy and a member of the Board of Directors of The
Peregrine Fund, Inc.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">John A. Thain, 47</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Mr.&nbsp;Thain has been our President and
Co-Chief Operating Officer since May 1999, and has been a
director since August&nbsp;1998. He was President of The Goldman
Sachs Group,&nbsp;L.P. from March&nbsp;1999 to May&nbsp;1999 and
Co-Chief Operating Officer from January&nbsp;1999 to
May&nbsp;1999. From December&nbsp;1994 to March&nbsp;1999, he
served as Chief Financial Officer and Head of Operations,
Technology and Finance. From July&nbsp;1995 to
September&nbsp;1997, he was also Co-Chief Executive Officer for
European Operations. Mr.&nbsp;Thain is not on the board of any
public companies other than Goldman Sachs. He is affiliated with
certain non-profit organizations, including as a member of The
MIT Corporation, the Dean&#146;s Advisory Council&nbsp;&#151;
MIT/ Sloan School of Management, INSEAD&nbsp;&#151;
U.S.&nbsp;National Advisory Board, the James Madison Council of
the Library of Congress and the Federal Reserve Bank of
New&nbsp;York&#146;s International Capital Markets Advisory
Committee. He is also a member of the French-American
Foundation, the Board of Trustees of the National Urban League
and The Trilateral Commission, as well as a governor of the New
York-Presbyterian Foundation, Inc., a trustee of
New&nbsp;York-Presbyterian Hospital, a General Trustee of Howard
University and Chairman of the US-Japan Private Sector/
Government Commission.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">John L. Thornton, 49</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Mr.&nbsp;Thornton has been our President and
Co-Chief Operating Officer since May&nbsp;1999, and has been a
director since August&nbsp;1998. He was President of The Goldman
Sachs Group,&nbsp;L.P. from March&nbsp;1999 to May&nbsp;1999 and
Co-Chief Operating Officer from January&nbsp;1999 to
May&nbsp;1999. From August&nbsp;1998 until January&nbsp;1999, he
had oversight responsibility for International Operations. From
September&nbsp;1996 until August&nbsp;1998, he was Chairman,
Goldman Sachs&nbsp;&#151; Asia, in addition to his senior
strategic responsibilities in Europe. From July&nbsp;1995 to
September&nbsp;1997, he was Co-Chief Executive Officer for
European Operations. Mr.&nbsp;Thornton is also on the board of
the following public companies other than Goldman Sachs: Ford
Motor Company, BskyB&nbsp;PLC, Laura Ashley Holdings&nbsp;plc
and Pacific Century Group, Inc. In addition, Mr.&nbsp;Thornton
is affiliated with certain non-profit organizations, including
as a member of the Council on Foreign Relations and a director
or trustee of the Asia Society, The Brookings Institution, The
Goldman Sachs Foundation, The Hotchkiss School, Morehouse
College, and the Tsinghua University School of Economics and
Management, and as a member of the Advisory Board of the Yale
School of Management.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">31
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">Lloyd C. Blankfein, 48</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Mr.&nbsp;Blankfein has been our Vice Chairman
since April&nbsp;2002. Mr.&nbsp;Blankfein has management
responsibility for the Fixed Income, Currency and Commodities
Division (FICC)&nbsp;and the Equities Division. Prior to
becoming Vice Chairman, he had been Co-Head of FICC since its
formation in 1997. Previously, he headed the J.&nbsp;Aron
Currency and Commodities Division since 1994. Mr.&nbsp;Blankfein
has been nominated to serve as director of Goldman Sachs and is
not on the board of any other public companies. He is affiliated
with certain non-profit organizations, including as Co-Chair of
the Harvard University Financial Aid Task Force and as a member
of the Executive Committee of the Harvard University Committee
on University Resources. Mr.&nbsp;Blankfein is also a former
Director of the Futures Industry Association and a former member
of the Foreign Exchange Committee of the Federal Reserve Bank of
New York.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">Robert S. Kaplan, 45</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Mr.&nbsp;Kaplan has been our Vice Chairman since
April&nbsp;2002. Mr.&nbsp;Kaplan has management responsibility
for the Investment Banking and Investment Management Divisions.
He served as global Co-Head of the Investment Banking Division
from 1999 through 2001 and was Co-Chief Operating Officer of
global Investment Banking from 1998 to 1999. Mr.&nbsp;Kaplan
became Head of the Americas Corporate Finance Department in
1994. Previously, he had been Head of Asia-Pacific Investment
Banking from 1990 through 1993. Mr.&nbsp;Kaplan is a director of
Bed Bath &#38; Beyond Inc., which is a public company. In
addition, Mr.&nbsp;Kaplan is affiliated with certain non-profit
organizations, including as Co-Chairman of the Board of The TEAK
Fellowship, Co-Chairman of the Board of Project A.L.S. and a
director of The Jewish Theological Seminary, Everybody Wins,
Inc. and The Jewish Museum.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">Kevin W. Kennedy, 54</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Mr.&nbsp;Kennedy has been our Executive Vice
President&nbsp;&#151; Human Capital Management since
December&nbsp;2001. From 1999 until 2001, he served as a member
of the Executive Office. From 1994 to 1999, Mr.&nbsp;Kennedy
served as Head of the Americas Group, a combination of Corporate
Finance, Investment Banking Services and Structured Finance for
the United States, Canada and Latin America, and, from 1988 to
1994, as Head of Corporate Finance. He is a life trustee and a
former Chairman of the Board of Hamilton College, a Managing
Director and Vice President of the Board of the Metropolitan
Opera, a trustee of the New York Public Library and an honorary
trustee of the Chewonki Foundation.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">Gregory K. Palm, 54</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Mr.&nbsp;Palm has been our General Counsel and
Executive Vice President and Head or Co-Head of the Legal
Department since May&nbsp;1999. He was General Counsel of The
Goldman Sachs Group,&nbsp;L.P. and Co-Head of the Legal
Department from 1992 to May&nbsp;1999. He also has senior
oversight responsibility for the firm&#146;s Compliance,
Management Controls and Tax Departments and is Co-Chairman of
the Global Compliance and Control Committee. From 1982 to 1992,
Mr.&nbsp;Palm was a partner in the law firm of
Sullivan&nbsp;&#38; Cromwell. Mr.&nbsp;Palm is a member of the
American Law Institute, the MIT Corporation Department of
Economics Visiting Committee and the Board of Trustees of the
Skowhegan School of Painting and Sculpture.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">Esta E. Stecher, 45</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Ms.&nbsp;Stecher has been our General Counsel and
Executive Vice President and Co-Head of the Legal Department
since December&nbsp;2000. From 1994 to 2000, she was Head of the
firm&#146;s Tax Department. She also has senior oversight
responsibility for the Compliance, Management Controls and Tax
Departments. She is also a trustee of The Goldman Sachs
Foundation. From 1990 to 1994, Ms.&nbsp;Stecher was a partner in
the law firm of Sullivan&nbsp;&#38; Cromwell.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">32
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">Robert K. Steel, 51</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Mr.&nbsp;Steel has been our Vice Chairman since
April&nbsp;2002. Mr.&nbsp;Steel has management responsibility
for FICC and the Equities Division. He served as Co-Head of the
Equities Division from 1998 through 2001, then as sole Head
until his appointment as a Vice Chairman of the firm. From 1994
to 1998, he was responsible for all institutional equities in
the United States. From 1988 to 1994, Mr.&nbsp;Steel was
responsible for the Equities Division in Europe. Mr.&nbsp;Steel
is a member of the NYSE, where he has served on various
committees, and is a member of the Board of Directors of the
Securities Industry Association. He is also Vice Chairman of
Duke University&#146;s Board of Trustees and Chairman of the
Duke University Management Co.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">David A. Viniar, 47</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Mr.&nbsp;Viniar has been our Chief Financial
Officer and Executive Vice President since May&nbsp;1999. He has
been the Head of the Operations, Technology and Finance Division
since December&nbsp;2002. He was Head of the Finance Division
and Co-Head of Credit Risk Management and Advisory and Firmwide
Risk from December&nbsp;2001 to December&nbsp;2002. He was
Co-Head of Operations, Finance and Resources from
March&nbsp;1999 to December&nbsp;2001. He was Chief Financial
Officer of The Goldman Sachs Group,&nbsp;L.P. from
March&nbsp;1999 to May&nbsp;1999. From July&nbsp;1998 until
March&nbsp;1999, he was Deputy Chief Financial Officer and from
1994 until July&nbsp;1998, he was Head of Finance, with
responsibility for Controllers and Treasury. From 1992 to 1994,
Mr.&nbsp;Viniar was Head of Treasury and prior to that was in
the Structured Finance Department of Investment Banking.
Mr.&nbsp;Viniar is a member of the Board of Trustees of
Children&#146;s Aid and Family Services, serves on the Board of
Trustees of Union College and is a member of the Board of
Trustees of the Financial Accounting Foundation.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">33
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<!-- link1 "PART II" -->

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">PART II</FONT></B>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="8%"></TD>
    <TD width="92%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><FONT size="2">Item&nbsp;5.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT size="2">Market for Registrant&#146;s Common Equity
    and Related Stockholder Matters</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The principal market on which our common stock is
traded is the New York Stock Exchange. Information relating to
the high and low sales prices per share on the New York Stock
Exchange for each full quarterly period during fiscal 2001 and
2002 is set forth under the caption &#147;Supplemental Financial
Information&nbsp;&#151; Common Stock Price Range&#148; on
page&nbsp;91 of the 2002 Annual Report to Shareholders, which is
incorporated herein by reference. As of January&nbsp;31, 2003,
there were 5,530 holders of record of our common stock.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">During fiscal 2001 and 2002, dividends of $0.12
per share of common stock were declared on December&nbsp;18,
2000, March&nbsp;19, 2001, June&nbsp;18, 2001,
September&nbsp;25, 2001, December&nbsp;19, 2001, March&nbsp;18,
2002, June&nbsp;19, 2002 and September&nbsp;23, 2002. The
holders of our common stock share proportionately on a per share
basis in all dividends and other distributions declared by our
board of directors.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The declaration of dividends by Goldman Sachs is
subject to the discretion of our board of directors. Our board
of directors will take into account such matters as general
business conditions, our financial results, capital
requirements, contractual, legal and regulatory restrictions on
the payment of dividends by us to our shareholders or by our
subsidiaries to us, the effect on our debt ratings and such
other factors as our board of directors may deem relevant. See
&#147;Business&nbsp;&#151; Regulation&#148; in Item&nbsp;1 of
this Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K for a discussion of
potential regulatory limitations on our receipt of funds from
our regulated subsidiaries.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On November&nbsp;20, 2002, our board of directors
authorized the repurchase of additional shares of The Goldman
Sachs Group, Inc.&#146;s common stock pursuant to our existing
share repurchase program. The repurchase program is being
effected from time to time, depending on market conditions and
other factors, through open market purchases and privately
negotiated transactions. The total remaining authorization under
the repurchase program was 17.2&nbsp;million shares as of
January&nbsp;31, 2003.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Information relating to compensation plans under
which equity securities of The Goldman Sachs Group, Inc. are
authorized for issuance is set forth under &#147;Equity
Compensation Plan Information&#148; on page&nbsp;15 of the Proxy
Statement for our 2003 Annual Meeting of Shareholders to be held
on April&nbsp;1, 2003 (the &#147;2003 Proxy Statement&#148;) and
all such information is incorporated herein by reference.

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<!-- link2 "Item 14. Controls and Procedures" -->

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="9%"></TD>
    <TD width="91%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><FONT size="2">Item&nbsp;14.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT size="2">Controls and Procedures</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Within the 90-day period prior to the filing of
this report, an evaluation was carried out under the supervision
and with the participation of Goldman Sachs&#146; management,
including our Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial
Officer, of the effectiveness of the design and operation of our
disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in
Rule&nbsp;13a-14(c) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934).
Based upon that evaluation, the Chief Executive Officer and
Chief Financial Officer concluded that the design and operation
of these disclosure controls and procedures were effective. No
significant changes were made in our internal controls or in
other factors that could significantly affect these controls
subsequent to the date of their evaluation.
</FONT>

<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">REPORT OF INDEPENDENT ACCOUNTANTS</FONT></B>

<P align="left">
<FONT size="2">To the Directors and Shareholders of
</FONT>

<DIV align="left">
<FONT size="2">The Goldman Sachs Group, Inc.:
</FONT>
</DIV>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Our audits of the consolidated financial
statements referred to in our report dated January&nbsp;27, 2003
appearing in the 2002 Annual Report to Shareholders of The
Goldman Sachs Group, Inc. and Subsidiaries (which report and
consolidated financial statements are incorporated by reference
in this Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K) also included an audit
of the financial statement schedule listed on page&nbsp;F-1 of
this Form&nbsp;10-K. In our opinion, this financial statement
schedule presents fairly, in all material respects, the
information set forth therein when read in conjunction with the
related consolidated financial statements.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<FONT size="2">/s/ PRICEWATERHOUSECOOPERS LLP
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<FONT size="2">New York, New York
</FONT>

<DIV align="left">
<FONT size="2">January&nbsp;27, 2003.
</FONT>
</DIV>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-2
</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<P align="right">
<B><FONT size="2">SCHEDULE I</FONT></B>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">THE GOLDMAN SACHS GROUP, INC.</FONT></B>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">CONDENSED STATEMENTS OF EARNINGS (PARENT
COMPANY ONLY)</FONT></B>

<CENTER>
<TABLE width="80%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="68%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

    <TD width="2%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

    <TD colspan="2"></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD colspan="11"></TD>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="2"></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD colspan="11" align="center" nowrap><B><FONT size="1">Year Ended November</FONT></B></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="2"></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD colspan="11" align="center" nowrap><HR size="1" noshade></TD>
</TR>

<TR>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">THE GOLDMAN SACHS GROUP, INC.</FONT></B>

<P align="center">

    <TD colspan="4"></TD>
    <TD></TD>

    <TD colspan="4"></TD>
    <TD></TD>
