<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Note 10.&nbsp;&nbsp;Goodwill And Identifiable Intangible Assets</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B><I>Goodwill</I></B></FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">As of November 2002, goodwill of
$2.86&nbsp;billion was included in &#147;Other
assets&#148; in the consolidated
statement of financial condition.
Prior to December&nbsp;1, 2001, goodwill
was amortized over periods of 15 to
20&nbsp;years on a straight-line basis.
The following table sets forth
reported net earnings and EPS, as
adjusted to exclude goodwill
amortization expense:
</FONT>

    <TD><DIV style="margin-left:10px; text-indent:-10px"><FONT size="2">Gross carrying amount</FONT></DIV></TD>

    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

</TABLE>
</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Identifiable intangible assets
consist primarily of specialist
rights and customer lists and are
amortized over a weighted average
life of approximately 21&nbsp;years.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Amortization expense associated with
identifiable intangible assets was
$127&nbsp;million, $115&nbsp;million and $7
million for the fiscal years ended
November 2002, November 2001 and
November 2000, respectively.
Estimated amortization expense for
existing identifiable intangible
assets is $129&nbsp;million for each of
the fiscal years ending November
2003 through November 2007.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Note 11.&nbsp;&nbsp;Employee Benefit Plans</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The firm sponsors various pension
plans and certain other
postretirement benefit plans,
primarily healthcare and life
insurance, which cover most
employees worldwide. The firm also
provides certain benefits to former
or inactive employees prior to
retirement. A summary of these plans
is set forth below:
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B><I>Defined Benefit Pension Plans and Postretirement Plans</I></B></FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The firm maintains a defined benefit
pension plan for substantially all
U.S. employees. Employees of certain
non-U.S. subsidiaries participate in
various local defined benefit plans.
These plans generally provide
benefits based on years of credited
service and a percentage of the
employee&#146;s eligible compensation. In
addition, the firm has unfunded
postretirement benefit plans that
provide medical and life insurance
for eligible retirees, employees and
dependents in the United States.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">78</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->

</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">For plans in which the accumulated
benefit obligation exceeded plan
assets, the aggregate projected
benefit obligation and accumulated
benefit obligation was $72&nbsp;million
and $55&nbsp;million, respectively, as of
November 2002, and $63&nbsp;million and
$46&nbsp;million, respectively, as of
November 2001. The fair value of
plan assets for each of these plans
was $39&nbsp;million and $35&nbsp;million as
of November 2002 and November 2001,
respectively.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">79</FONT>

</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">For measurement purposes, an annual
growth rate in the per capita cost
of covered healthcare benefits of
11% was assumed for the fiscal year
ending November 2003. The rate was
assumed to decrease ratably to 5%
for the fiscal year ending November
2009 and remain at that level
thereafter.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">80</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<P align="center"><B><FONT size="2">THE GOLDMAN SACHS GROUP, INC. and
SUBSIDIARIES<BR>
&nbsp;<BR>
NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued)</FONT></B>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The assumed cost of healthcare has an effect on the amounts reported for the
firm&#146;s postretirement plans. A 1% change in the assumed healthcare cost trend
rate would have the following effects:
</FONT>
<CENTER>
<TABLE cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="52%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="7"><FONT size="2">1% Increase</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="7"><FONT size="2">1% Decrease</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B><I>Defined Contribution Plans</I></B></FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The firm contributes to
employer-sponsored U.S. and non-U.S.
defined contribution plans. The
firm&#146;s contribution to these plans
was $154&nbsp;million, $193&nbsp;million and
$129&nbsp;million for 2002, 2001 and
2000, respectively. Contributions in
2002 and 2001 each reflect a full
year of contributions with respect
to employees added as a result of
the firm&#146;s combination with SLK.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The firm has also established a
nonqualified defined contribution
plan (the Plan) for certain senior
employees. Shares of common stock
contributed to the Plan and
outstanding as of November 2002 were
8.6&nbsp;million. The shares of common
stock will vest and generally be
distributable to the participant on
specified future dates if the
participant satisfies certain
conditions and the participant&#146;s
employment with the firm has not
been terminated, with certain
exceptions for terminations of
employment due to death or a change
in control. Dividends on the
underlying shares of common stock
are paid currently to the
participants. Forfeited shares
remain in the Plan and are
reallocated to other participants.
Contributions to the Plan are
expensed on the date of grant. Plan
expense was immaterial for the years
ended November 2002, November 2001
and November 2000.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Note 12. Employee Incentive Plans</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B><I>Stock Incentive Plan</I></B></FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The firm sponsors a stock incentive
plan that provides for grants of
incentive stock options,
nonqualified stock options, stock
appreciation rights, dividend
equivalent rights, restricted stock,
restricted stock units and other
stock-based awards.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The total number of shares of common
stock that may be issued under the
stock incentive plan through fiscal
2002 may not exceed 300&nbsp;million
shares. As of November 2002 and
November 2001, 128.6&nbsp;million shares
and 135.0&nbsp;million shares,
respectively, were available for
grant under the stock incentive
plan, after considering stock-based
compensation awards that were issued
subsequent to year end, as part of
year-end compensation.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B><I>Restricted Stock Units</I></B></FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The firm issued restricted stock
units to employees under the stock
incentive plan, primarily in
connection with its initial public
offering, acquisitions and as part
of year-end compensation. Of the
total restricted stock units
outstanding as of November 2002 and
November 2001, (i)&nbsp;29.9&nbsp;million
units and 41.7&nbsp;million units,
respectively, required future
service as a condition to the
delivery of the underlying shares of
common stock and (ii)&nbsp;18.3&nbsp;million
units and 25.6&nbsp;million units,
respectively, did not require future
service. In all cases, delivery of
the underlying shares of common
stock is conditioned on the
grantee&#146;s satisfying certain other
requirements outlined in the award
agreements.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">81</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="1"><sup>(1)</sup></FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="1">Includes restricted stock units granted in connection with the
combination with SLK and restricted stock units granted to employees,
subsequent to year end, as part of year-end compensation.</FONT></TD>
</TR>

    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="1"><sup>(2)</sup></FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="1">Includes restricted stock units granted to employees subsequent to year end
as part of year-end compensation.</FONT></TD>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Total employee stock compensation
expense, net of forfeitures, was
$645&nbsp;million, $798&nbsp;million and
$1.35&nbsp;billion for the years ended
November 2002, November 2001 and
November 2000, respectively.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B><I>Stock Options</I></B></FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">In general, stock options granted to
employees in connection with the
firm&#146;s initial public offering vest
and become exercisable in equal
installments on or about the third,
fourth and fifth anniversaries of
the grant date. Stock options
granted to employees subsequent to
the firm&#146;s initial public offering
generally vest as outlined in the
applicable stock option agreement
and first become exercisable on the
third anniversary of the grant date.
All employee stock option agreements
provide that vesting is accelerated
in certain circumstances, such as
upon retirement, death and extended
absence. In general, all stock
options expire on the tenth
anniversary of the grant date,
although they may be subject to
earlier termination or cancellation
in certain circumstances in
accordance with the terms of the
firm&#146;s stock incentive plan and the
applicable stock option agreement.
The dilutive effect of the firm&#146;s
outstanding stock options is
included in &#147;Average common shares
outstanding &#151; Diluted,&#148; on the
consolidated statements of earnings.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">82</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>

SUBSIDIARES<BR>

    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right"><FONT size="2">52</FONT></TD>

    <TD nowrap align="right"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

    <TD nowrap><FONT size="2">)</FONT></TD>
</TR>

</TR>
<TR valign="bottom" bgcolor="#eeeeee">
    <TD colspan="2"><DIV style="margin-left:10px; text-indent:-10px"><FONT size="2">Net tax expense</FONT></DIV></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right"><FONT size="2"><B>$</B></FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right"><FONT size="2"><B>1,139</B></FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

    <TD nowrap align="center"><HR noshade size="4"></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Deferred income taxes reflect the
net tax effects of temporary
differences between the financial
reporting and tax bases of assets
and liabilities. These temporary
differences result in taxable or
deductible amounts in future years
and are measured using the tax rates
and laws that will be in effect when
such differences are expected to
reverse.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Significant components of the firm&#146;s deferred tax assets and liabilities are
set forth below:
</FONT>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="1"><sup>(1)</sup></FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="1">Relates primarily to the ability to utilize certain state and local and
foreign tax credits.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The firm permanently reinvests
eligible earnings of certain foreign
subsidiaries that were incorporated
for U.S. income tax purposes at the
end of 2001 and, accordingly, does
not accrue any U.S. income taxes
that would arise if such earnings
were repatriated. As of November
2002, this policy resulted in an
unrecognized net deferred tax
liability of approximately $33
million attributable to reinvested
earnings of approximately $209
million. Additionally, during 2002,
the valuation allowance was
increased by $10&nbsp;million, primarily
due to an increase in certain state
and local and foreign tax credits.
Acquired net operating loss
carryforwards of approximately $58
million are subject to annual
limitations on utilization and will
begin to expire in 2018.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">84</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Tax benefits of approximately $119
million in 2002, $123&nbsp;million in
2001 and $116&nbsp;million in 2000,
related to the delivery of
restricted stock units and the
exercise of options, were credited
directly to &#147;Additional paid-in
capital&#148; in the consolidated
statements of financial condition
and changes in shareholders&#146; equity.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Note 14. Regulated Subsidiaries</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">GS&#038;Co. and Spear, Leeds and Kellogg,
L.P. are registered U.S.
broker-dealers and futures
commission merchants subject to Rule
15c3-1 of the Securities and
Exchange Commission and Rule&nbsp;1.17 of
the Commodity Futures Trading
Commission, which specify uniform
minimum net capital requirements, as
defined, for their registrants. They
have elected to compute their net
capital in accordance with the
&#147;Alternative Net Capital
Requirement&#148; as permitted by Rule
15c3-1. As of November 2002 and
November 2001, GS&#038;Co. had regulatory
net capital, as defined, of $4.75
billion and $4.59&nbsp;billion
respectively, which exceeded the
amounts required by $4.09&nbsp;billion
and $3.91&nbsp;billion, respectively. As
of November 2002 and November 2001,
Spear, Leeds and Kellogg, L.P. had
regulatory net capital, as defined,
of $1.28&nbsp;billion and $952&nbsp;million,
respectively, which exceeded the
amounts required by $1.24&nbsp;billion
and $907&nbsp;million, respectively.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">GSI, a registered U.K.
broker-dealer, is subject to the
capital requirements of The
Financial Services Authority, and
GSJL, a Tokyo-based broker-dealer,
is subject to the capital
requirements of the Financial
Services Agency. As of November 2002
and November 2001, GSI and GSJL were
in compliance with their local
capital adequacy requirements.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Certain other subsidiaries of the
firm are also subject to capital
adequacy requirements promulgated by
authorities of the countries in
which they operate. As of November
2002 and November 2001, these
subsidiaries were in compliance with
their local capital adequacy
requirements.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Note 15. Business Segments</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">In reporting to management, the
firm&#146;s operating results are
categorized into the following three
segments: Investment Banking,
Trading and Principal Investments,
and Asset Management and Securities
Services. The Investment Banking and
Trading and Principal Investments
segments were previously aggregated
into one reporting segment &#151; Global
Capital Markets.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B><I>Investment Banking</I></B></FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The Investment Banking segment
provides a broad range of investment
banking services to a diverse group
of corporations, financial
institutions, governments and
individuals. Investment banking
activities are divided into two
categories:
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2"><B>Financial Advisory.</B>
Financial Advisory includes
advisory assignments with
respect to mergers and
acquisitions, divestitures,
corporate defense activities,
restructurings and spin-offs;
and</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2"><B>Underwriting.</B>
Underwriting includes public
offerings and private
placements of equity and debt
securities.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B><I>Trading and Principal Investments</I></B></FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The Trading and Principal
Investments business facilitates
customer transactions with a diverse
group of corporations, financial
institutions, governments and
individuals and takes proprietary
positions through market making in,
and trading of, fixed income and
equity products, currencies,
commodities, and swaps and other
derivatives. In addition, the firm
engages in floor-based and
electronic market making as a
specialist on U.S. equities and
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">85</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<P align="center"><B><FONT size="2">THE GOLDMAN SACHS GROUP, INC. and
SUBSIDIARIES<BR>
&nbsp;<BR>
NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued)</FONT></B>


<P align="left"><FONT size="2">options exchanges. Trading and
Principal Investments is divided
into three categories:
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2"><B>FICC. </B>The firm makes
markets in and trades
interest rate and credit
products, currencies and
commodities, structures and
enters into a wide variety of
derivative transactions, and
engages in proprietary
trading;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2"><B>Equities. </B>The firm makes
markets in, acts as a
specialist for, and trades
equities and equity-related
products, structures and
enters into equity derivative
transactions, and engages in
proprietary trading; and</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2"><B>Principal Investments.</B>
Principal Investments
primarily represents net
revenues from the firm&#146;s
merchant banking investments.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B><I>Asset Management and Securities Services</I></B></FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The Asset Management and Securities
Services segment includes services
related to the following:
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2"><B>Asset Management. </B>Asset
Management generates
management fees by providing
investment advisory services
to a diverse client base of
institutions and individuals;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2"><B>Securities Services.</B>
Securities Services includes
prime brokerage, financing
services and securities
lending, and the firm&#146;s
matched book businesses, all
of which generate revenues
primarily in the form of
interest rate spreads or
fees; and</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2"><B>Commissions. </B>Commissions
includes fees from executing
and clearing client
transactions on major stock,
options and futures markets
worldwide. Commissions also
includes revenues from the
increased share of the income
and gains derived from the
firm&#146;s merchant banking funds
when the return on a
fund&#146;s investments exceeds
certain threshold returns.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B><I>Basis of Presentation</I></B></FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">In reporting segments, certain of
the firm&#146;s business lines have been
aggregated where they have similar
economic characteristics and are
similar in each of the following
areas: (i)&nbsp;the nature of the
services they provide, (ii)&nbsp;their
methods of distribution, (iii)&nbsp;the
types of clients they serve and (iv)
the regulatory environments in which
they operate.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The cost structures of each of the
firm&#146;s segments are broadly similar
to that of the firm taken as a whole
in that they are primarily
influenced by discretionary
compensation, headcount and levels
of business activity. The firm&#146;s
overall compensation and benefits
expenses are generally targeted at
50% (plus or minus a few percentage
points) of consolidated net
revenues. A substantial portion of
the firm&#146;s compensation expense
represents discretionary bonuses.
Compensation expense within a
segment reflects, among other
factors, the overall performance of
the firm as well as the performance
of the individual business unit.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The firm allocates revenues and
expenses among the three segments.
Due to the integrated nature of the
business segments, estimates and
judgments have been made in
allocating certain revenue and
expense items. Transactions between
segments are based on specific
criteria or approximate third-party
rates. Total operating expenses
include corporate items that have
not been allocated to individual
business segments. The allocation
process is based on the manner in
which management views the business
of the firm.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The segment information presented in
the table below is prepared
according to the following
methodologies:
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">Revenues and expenses
directly associated with each
segment are included in
determining pre-tax earnings.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">Net revenues in the firm&#146;s
segments include allocations
of interest income and
interest expense to specific
securities, commodities and
other positions in relation
to the cash generated by, or
funding requirements of, the
underlying positions. Net
interest is included within
segment net revenues as it is
consistent with the way in
which management assesses
segment performance.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">Overhead expenses not
directly allocable to
specific segments are
allocated ratably based on
direct segment expenses.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">The nonrecurring expenses
associated with the firm&#146;s
acquisition awards and
conversion to corporate form
and related transactions are
not allocated to individual
segments as management
excludes them in evaluating
segment performance.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">86</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">88</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<P align="CENTER"><FONT size="2"><B>THE GOLDMAN SACHS GROUP, INC. and
SUBSIDIARIES</B></FONT>
<P align="CENTER"><FONT size="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
STATEMENTS (Continued)</B></FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B><I>Geographic Information</I></B></FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Due to the highly integrated nature
of international financial markets,
the firm manages its businesses
based on the profitability of the
enterprise as a whole. Accordingly,
management believes that
profitability by geographic region
is not necessarily meaningful.
The firm&#146;s revenues, expenses and
identifiable assets are generally
allocated based on the country of
domicile of the legal entity
providing the service.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The following table sets forth the total net revenues, pre-tax earnings and
identifiable assets of the firm and its consolidated subsidiaries by
geographic region allocated on the basis described above:
</FONT>

    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="1">Includes the following expenses that have not been allocated to the
firm&#146;s segments: (i)&nbsp;amortization of employee initial public offering awards
of $212&nbsp;million, $363&nbsp;million and $428&nbsp;million for the years ended November
2002, November 2001 and November 2000, respectively, and (ii)&nbsp;non-recurring
acquisition awards of $290&nbsp;million related to the firm&#146;s combination with SLK
for the year ended November 2000.</FONT></TD>

<P align="right"><FONT size="2">EXHIBIT&nbsp;13.3</FONT>



<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>SUPPLEMENTAL FINANCIAL INFORMATION</B></FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>Quarterly Results (unaudited)</B></FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The following represents the firm&#146;s unaudited quarterly results for 2002 and
2001. These quarterly results were prepared in accordance with U.S. generally
accepted accounting principles and reflect all adjustments that are, in the
opinion of the management, necessary for a fair presentation of the results.
These adjustments are of a normal recurring nature.
</FONT>

<DIV>
<HR size="1" width="18%" align="left" noshade></DIV>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="1"><sup>(1)</sup></FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="1">As a partnership, payments for services rendered by profit-participating
limited partners were accounted for as distributions of partners&#146; capital
rather than as compensation and benefits expense. As a result, pre-tax
earnings in 1998 is not comparable with 2002, 2001, 2000 or 1999.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="1"><sup>(2)</sup></FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="1">Excludes employees of Goldman Sachs&#146; property management subsidiaries.
Substantially all of the costs of these employees are reimbursed to Goldman
Sachs by the real estate investment funds to which these subsidiaries provide
property management services.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="1"><sup>(3)</sup></FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="1">Includes merchant banking, quantitative asset allocation and other
similar funds that the firm manages, as well as funds where the firm
recommends one or more subadvisors for the firm&#146;s clients.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="1"><sup>(4)</sup></FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="1">In 2000, pre-tax earnings included a charge of $290&nbsp;million ($180&nbsp;million
after taxes) related to the firm&#146;s combination with SLK. Excluding this
charge, diluted earnings per share were $6.35.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="1"><sup>(5)</sup></FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="1">In 1999, pre-tax earnings were reduced by nonrecurring expenses of $2.26
billion associated with the conversion to corporate form and the charitable
contribution to The Goldman Sachs Foundation of $200&nbsp;million made at the time
of the initial public offering.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="1"><sup>(6)</sup></FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="1">Includes 2,600 employees related to the combination with SLK.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<P>&nbsp;
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">92</FONT>
</BODY>
</HTML>

</TEXT>
</DOCUMENT>
<DOCUMENT>
<TYPE>EX-21.1
<SEQUENCE>13
<FILENAME>y83718exv21w1.htm
<DESCRIPTION>EX-21.1 LIST OF SUBSIDIARIES
<TEXT>
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>EX-21.1 LIST OF SUBSIDIARIES</TITLE>
</HEAD>
<BODY bgcolor="#FFFFFF">
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<P align="right"><FONT size="2">EXHIBIT&nbsp;21.1</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">Significant Subsidiaries of the Registrant</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The following are significant subsidiaries of The Goldman Sachs Group, Inc. as
of November&nbsp;29, 2002 and the states or jurisdictions in which they are
organized. Indentation indicates the principal parent of each subsidiary.
Except as otherwise specified, in each case The Goldman Sachs Group, Inc. owns,
directly or indirectly, at least 99% of the voting securities of each
subsidiary. The names of particular subsidiaries have been omitted because,
considered in the aggregate as a single subsidiary, they would not constitute,
as of the end of the year covered by this report, a &#147;significant subsidiary&#148; as
that term is defined in Rule&nbsp;1-02(w) of Regulation&nbsp;S-X under the Securities
Exchange Act of 1934.
</FONT>
<CENTER>

<TYPE>EX-23.1
<SEQUENCE>14
<FILENAME>y83718exv23w1.htm
<DESCRIPTION>EX-23.1 CONSENT OF PRICEWATERHOUSECOOPERS LLP
<TEXT>
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>EX-23.1 CONSENT OF PRICEWATERHOUSECOOPERS LLP</TITLE>
</HEAD>
<BODY bgcolor="#FFFFFF">
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<P align="right"><FONT size="2">EXHIBIT 23.1</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>CONSENT OF INDEPENDENT ACCOUNTANTS</B></FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We hereby consent to the incorporation by reference in the Registration
Statements on Form&nbsp;S-3 (File Nos. 333-34042, 333-90677, 333-75213, 333-36178,
333-49958, 333-63082, 333-74006 and 333-101093) and on Form&nbsp;S-8 (File Nos.
333-80839 and 333-42068) of our report dated January&nbsp;27, 2003 relating to the
financial statements of The Goldman Sachs Group, Inc. and subsidiaries, which
appears in the 2002 Annual Report to Shareholders and is incorporated by
reference in this Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K for the year ended November&nbsp;29,
2002. We also consent to the incorporation by reference in the Registration
Statements on Form&nbsp;S-3 (File Nos. 333-34042, 333-90677, 333-75213, 333-36178,
333-49958, 333-63082, 333-74006 and 333-101093) and on Form&nbsp;S-8 (File Nos.
333-80839 and 333-42068) of our reports dated January&nbsp;27, 2003 relating to the
Financial Statement Schedule and Selected Financial Data, which appear in this
Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">/s/ PRICEWATERHOUSECOOPERS LLP</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">New York, New York<BR>
February&nbsp;27, 2003</FONT>


<P align="center"><FONT size="2"></FONT>




</BODY>
</HTML>

</TEXT>
</DOCUMENT>
<DOCUMENT>
<TYPE>EX-99.1
<SEQUENCE>15
<FILENAME>y83718exv99w1.htm
<DESCRIPTION>EX-99.1: OPINION OF PRICEWATERHOUSECOOPERS LLP
<TEXT>
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>EX-99.1: OPINION OF PRICEWATERHOUSECOOPERS LLP</TITLE>
</HEAD>
<BODY bgcolor="#FFFFFF">
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<P align="right"><FONT size="2">EXHIBIT 99.1</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>REPORT OF INDEPENDENT ACCOUNTANTS</B></FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">To the Directors and Shareholders of<BR>
The Goldman Sachs Group, Inc.:</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We have audited the consolidated financial statements of The Goldman Sachs
Group, Inc. and subsidiaries (the &#147;Company&#148;) at November&nbsp;29, 2002 and
November&nbsp;30, 2001, and for each of the three fiscal years in the period ended
November&nbsp;29, 2002 and have issued our report thereon appearing on page 60 of
the Company&#146;s Annual Report to Shareholders, which expresses an unqualified
opinion, dated January&nbsp;27, 2003. Such consolidated statements and our report
thereon are incorporated by reference in Part II, Item&nbsp;8 &#147;Financial Statements
and Supplementary Data,&#148; of this Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We have also previously audited, in accordance with auditing standards
generally accepted in the United States of America, the consolidated statements
of financial condition at November&nbsp;24, 2000, November&nbsp;26, 1999 and November
27, 1998, and the related consolidated statements of earnings, changes in
shareholders&#146; equity and partners&#146; capital, cash flows and comprehensive income for the years ended
November&nbsp;26, 1999 and November&nbsp;27, 1998 (none of which are presented herein);
we expressed unqualified opinions on those consolidated financial statements.
In our opinion, the information set forth in the selected financial data for
each of the five years in the period ended November&nbsp;29, 2002, appearing on page
92 of the Company&#146;s Annual Report to Shareholders, which is incorporated by
reference in Part II, Item&nbsp;6 of this Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K, is fairly
stated, in all material respects, in relation to the consolidated financial
statements from which it has been derived.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">/s/ PRICEWATERHOUSECOOPERS LLP</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">New York, New York<BR>
January&nbsp;27, 2003</FONT>


<P align="center"><FONT size="2"></FONT>




</BODY>
</HTML>

</TEXT>
